title.narrative: Save the Children Afghanistan, Child protection 2016-2021

description.narrative: The overall objective of the intervention is to strengthened child protection prevention initiatives and quality access to child protection response services and reduce instances of violence, exploitation and neglect of children. Specifically, the project seeks to strengthen child protection systems at the national, provincial, district and community level to protect children at risk of abuse, exploitation, violence and neglect. Following are the results to be achieved at outcome level: Result 1: Strengthened community and formal government child protection systems improve access to and utilization of preventive and response services. Result 2: Violence against children is no longer tolerated in schools and at homes. Result 3: Children involved in or at risk of entering harmful work can access adequate support and protection that reduce their risk and improves their own and their families' livelihood opportunities as a way out of hazardous work. Result 4: Local Civil Society organizations (CSOs) demonstrate enhanced organizational operation capacity and more specific capacity in child rights and protection programming. Result 5: Community institutions, including those led by children and youth, are better able to respond to disasters affecting them. Result 6: Boys and girls are protected from the direct impact of conflict through the prevention and response to recruitment and use by armed forces or armed groups and indirect impact through awareness-raising and community-based risk reduction activities (Nangarhar province).

Den föreslagna insatsen är en fortsättning av Rädda Barnens/Save the Childrens projekt för barns rätt till trygghet och skydd i Afghanistan (som pågått 2013 - 2015). Den nya insatsen är planerad att pågå 2016-2019 i sex provinser. Fem av provinserna är samma som i projektets första fas: Nangarhar, Sa-re-Pul, Jawzjan, Balkh och Kabul. En sjätte provins, Faryad, har tillkommit i och med att en humanitär komponent tagits över från Rädda Barnens humanitära barnrättsprogram i Afghanistan. Det är ett led i Sidas ansträngningar att öka arbetet med transition, dvs. överbryggning mellan humanitärt stöd och utvecklingsstöd. Möjligheten fanns i och med att Rädda Barnen varit verksamt med båda stödformerna i Afghanistan. Nu ges det humanitära arbetet möjlighet att arbeta mer med långsiktigt stöd i den svåra utdragna konflikten. Den humanitära komponenten och transitionen ska utvärderas under år två.
Det övergripande målet för insatsen är att stärka barns rätt till trygghet och skydd, på en nationell, provinsiell, distrikt- och samhällsnivå i Afghanistan och att minska förekomsten av exploatering, försummelse, våld och övergrepp mot barn. Insatsen är ett projekt.
Projektet kommer att inledas med en fem månader lång s.k. "Inception phase", en inledningsfas med start i januari 2016 och rapporteras i en slutrapport i juni 2016.
Konfliktkänslighet är A och O givet den svåra situationen för mänskliga rättigheter i Afghanistan. Den inledande beredningen föreslog en projektperiod på tre år. Huvudberedningen och detta beslut föreslår en projektperiod på fyra år, då en fyraårig insats har också bättre förutsättningar att mäta resultat. Resultatstrategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med Afghanistan 2015 - 2019 ger också utrymme för det. Insatsens totala budget ligger i samband med ansökan på 49 700 000 SEK.
Insatsen har förlängts till 2020 och är därmed på totalt 62 700 000 SEK.
Sida är den enda givaren.

The proposed intervention will build and expand on the previous project phase 2013-2015. The project will be implemented during the four-year period from 2016 to 2019 in six provinces. Five of the provinces are the same as in the previous project phase: Nangarhar, Sa-re-Pul, Jawzjan, Balkh and Kabul. An additional sixth province is added; Faryab as an additional humanitarian component was included in the project as transition from Save the Children's humanitarian work in Afghanistan. This is a part of Sida’s efforts to link humanitarian assistance with development aid.
The overall objective of this program is strengthened child protection prevention initiatives and quality access to child protection response services reduce instances of violence, exploitation and neglect of children. Specifically, the program seeks to strengthen child protection systems at the national, provincial, district and community level to protect children at risk of abuse, exploitation, violence and neglect.
The project will begin with a five-month "Inception Phase starting in January 2016 and be reported in an inception report in June 2016.
Conflict sensitivity is key, given the difficult situation of human rights in Afghanistan. The initial assessment suggested a project period of three years. The appraisal, and this decision is proposing a project period of four years as a four-year effort is better placed to measure results. The Results Strategy for Development Cooperation with Afghanistan 2015 - 2019 also allows for this. The total budget as of the application was 49.7 million SEK.
The contribution has been extended until 2020 and the total budget is 62.7 million SEK.
Sida is the only donor.

participating-org.narrative: Save the Children - donor country office

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.

10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.

description.narrative: Save the Children International Afghanistan (SCI-A) has been able to successfully deliver results through formal partnership with three Non-Governmental Organisations namely; Help The Afghan Children organisation (HTAC), Organisation of Human Welfare (OHW) and Humanitarian Assistance and Development Association for Afghanistan (HADAAF). These partners have demonstrated improved capacity to implement the project in five out of six targeted provinces with technical support from SCI-A child protection team. The provinces are Kabul, Balkh, Nangarhar, Faryab, Jawzjan and Sar-i-Pul. An external evaluation of the project that was carried out in 2019 found that the project has made strides to improve and strengthen Afghanistan's Child Protection (CP) system in the six targeted provinces. Evidence show that the project has strengthened the child protection network structures and coordination among Child Protection Agencies, CSOs and local communities. This has contributed to collective effort in preventing and responding to violence, exploitation, neglect and abuse. Through Community Children Centre (CCC) interventions, children reported improved confidence, increased self-esteem, and improved communication skills with their friends and parents. Children have also been empowered with knowledge about their rights and expressed a desire to go to school and not enter into early marriage. The project has also successfully raised awareness amongst teachers, parents and children on the implications on violence against children. Though contributions made by the project have been successful in reducing vulnerabilities and addressing child protection issues, more must be done to scale up SCI-A's interventions in the targeted locations to continue to address persistent and emerging child protection issues linked to protracted conflict, environmental crises and the COVID-19 epidemic. SCI-A documented a significant increase in child recruitment during the second quarter of 2020 as compared to previous quarters and reports indicate that girls are at increased risk of exploitation, abuse and violence due to exacerbated poverty forcing families to resort to negative coping strategies such as early and forced marriage.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
